text.tspan: On miss trials, target pixels not important for
larger data set, more set sizes
Images from Pascal VOC dataset, used to create the Visual Search Difficulty dataset.
Alexnet, trained with weights randomly initialized
Alexnet, weights pre-trained on ImageNet dataset

flowRoot.flowPara: Behavior of neural network models performing visual search tasks
David Nicholson, Astrid Prinz. Emory University, Biology department.
nicholdav@gmail.com nickledave nicholdav
Introduction
Results
Methods
Biases learned from natural images cause neural networks to "behave" like humans performing visual search
Visual search
Results, continued
Acknowledgements
Conclusions
• for details, please see: https://github.com/NickleDave/visual-search-nets
Impact of target-distractor features on CNN accuracy consistent with humans
• Behavior of CNN models depends greatly on hyperparameters and training data
• Behavior analysis and visual explanation techniques suggest models map pixels to output, do not represent target
• In spite of this, CNNs may predict target-distractor discriminability in humans
◦ similar to ideal observer models

Research funded by the Lifelong Learning Machines program, DARPA/Microsystems Technology Office, DARPA cooperative agreement HR0011-18-2-0019. David Nicholson was partially supported by the 2017 William K. and Katherine W. Estes Fund to F. Pestilli, R. Goldstone and L. Smith, Indiana University Bloomington
Question: can visual search behavior be explained by object recognition?
Approach: adapt trained networks to visual search tasks, using transfer learning methods from machine learning
Further analysis suggests this is because of how networks map pixels to output

text.tspan: Accuracy always lower when target is present
Note that network sees many more distractors during training

flowRoot.flowPara: Lab visual search tasks focus on how visual system integrates single features (color, orientation)
but real-world visual search involves
Currently, the best models of object recognition are neural networks
• fit by optimizing for task
performance on image recognition
